 1. THE ECONOMY 1.1 Jamaica, a small island economy in the Caribbean, has a total area of 11,000 km 2 and a population estimated at 2.5 million (1994 GNP per capita is US$1,420). About 45% of the land is used for agriculture. About 55% of the population, which increased by 0.9 percent in 1993, lives in urban areas. The country is well endowed with natural resources, has a relatively well educated and skilled labor force, enjoys proximity to North American markets, and has a developed financial system. It is wholly reliant on imported oil for commercial energy consumption. 1.2 The economy is vulnerable to external factors such as foreign demand for bauxite/alumina and tourism, its key exports, and the price of oil. The 1994 Country Economic Memorandum' (CEM) presents a vision of how the economy can make the transition from stabilization to growth and reduce poverty through economic development. The following sections summarize the CEM findings. A. Recent Economic Developments 1.3 After rapid development in the 60s, with growth rates on the order of 5%, fueled by foreign investment in mining and tourism, as well as favorable terms of trade, the economy declined and stagnated in the 70s and 80s. Many of the problems associated with this situation can be traced to external shocks, excessive government intervention, import-substitution policies and pervasive administrative controls. Expansion of the public sector crowded out the private sector and increased the external debt which doubled between 1980 and 1985, reaching US$4 billion. 1.4 In the second half of the 80s, economic policies were revised, the public sector deficit was reduced, the import tariff system was restructured, many subsidies were eliminated and some trade restrictions were lifted. From 1987 to 1993 GDP grew at an average rate of 3%; however, growth has been below 2% in 1993 and 1994. 1.5 At present, Jamaica has a long-awaited breathing space in which to sustain and complete the structural reforms necessary to restore growth. For the first time in almost a decade, the country does not face a major financial crisis, macroeconomic imbalance, or negative external shock. B. CEM Policy Recommendations 1.6 The CEM emphasizes the following elements for achieving accelerated and sustainable growth: 'Jamaica- A strategy for growth and poverty reduction.  * Government should focus its efforts on tasks that the private sector cannot perform adequately and should withdraw from those which can better be managed by private enterprise; * Overall economic policy should seek to assure macroeconomic stability in order to attract investors; * Public expenditures should be targeted towards infrastructure, environmental protection and human resource development; * Efforts to reduce crime and protect property should be increased in order for market forces, and policies that work through them, to have their desired effects; and * Economic goals should be achieved through the regulatory and incentive structures rather than through budget and spending processes. C. Government Economic Policy 1.7 Since 1989, the Government has embarked on an accelerated program of economic reform involving liberalization, deregulation and privatization. These are aimed at enhancing economic performance and improving social welfare over the medium term. As articulated in its current Medium Term Reform Program (1992/93-1995/96) these reforms continued to focus on reducing the role of the public sector in commercially- oriented and industrial activities while creating a competitive and facilitative environment to stimulate private investment and export. Under this program, real GDP growth is targeted to improve to 3.5 percent by the mid-1990s. 1.8 Government policy has been largely successful in applying these policies: * On the macroeconomic front, the public sector continues to generate surpluses in recent years; * Average inflation was reduced from 77.3 per cent in 1992 to about 25% in 1993-94; * The currency has traded freely in the parallel market and foreign exchange deposits have grown from zero to over $500 million, * Financial sector policy has improved greatly in the past five years by opening more to international markets, evening out the regulatory framework for different categories of financial institutions, and lessening the requirement to finance public debt;
 - 3 - * The Jamaican Stock Exchange, although very small, grew rapidly in the early 1990s (it was the fastest growing market in the world in 1992); and * Privatization has proceeded successfully, with Bank support through the Private Sector Development Adjustment Loan; over 50 entities have been divested and at least an equal number are slated for privatization. 1.9 GOJ's economic objectives consist of supporting the stabilization program and seeking sustained improvements in the public finances. GOJ is committed to continue reducing the size and scope of the public sector and to stimulate efficient investment and growth in the private sector. The GOJ has circulated for comment an Industrial Strategy which outlines the tactics for growth. A number of externally-assisted reforms are also taking place, such as the Bank-supported Tax Administration Reform Project (loan amount US$13.2 million) which addresses the need to broaden the tax base, improve tax collection and eliminate distortions. These efforts will serve to enhance recently implemented tariff and customs reforms. D. Bank Lending Strategy 1.10 The Bank's Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), attached to the Reform of Secondary Education Project (March 1993), updates the development agenda of GOJ. The Bank Group's current assistance strategy includes the Private Sector Development Adjustment Loan approved on June 15, 1993, designed to support trade reforms, the privatization program, and other measures to increase the incentives for private investment. A loan for the reform of secondary education in Jamaica was approved on March 25, 1993, and a loan for Private Investment and Export Development was approved on March 24, 1994. Future Bank lending would consist largely of investment loan financing, tax administration reform, public sector modernization, transport, and other infrastructure development, social investments, and private sector development.
 - 4 - 2. THE ENERGY SECTOR A. Background 2.1 Jamaica's sources of indigenous energy are limited, comprised of a relatively small hydropower potential, bagasse and peat. The country therefore relies on imports, mainly oil, to meet its energy needs. Hydropower potential in the country amounts to about 114 MW, of which 24 MW have been developed to date (about 4% of total installed generation capacity). At present there are eight hydroelectric power plants which range in capacity from 0.2 MW to 6 MW. Hydropower potential which may be economically developed during the next 15-20 years is estimated at about 90 MW. Peat is the only indigenous fuel available in Jamaica in relatively significant quantities; however, the economic viability of peat development has not been proven and its adverse environmental implications have deterred its use. Additional energy resources (other than fuelwood which is used to produce charcoal) include substantial amounts of bagasse which is used by the sugar industry as fuel for industrial steam and electricity generation. GOJ has tried unsuccessfully to broaden and develop the country's indigenous sources of energy through on-shore and off-shore drilling. Solar energy promises some economic potential in the form of domestic water heating and crop drying. Barring significant discoveries of oil and gas, or unforeseen technological breakthroughs, the country will continue to rely on imported oil to meet most of its energy requirements. B. Institutions and Sector Organization 2.2 The Ministry of Public Utilities and Transport (MPUT) is responsible for overseeing the energy sector and coordinating policies with the Planning Institute of Jamaica (PIOJ). In order to bring together various entities and agencies involved, to implement energy sector policy with private sector participation, a Minister's Steering Committee on Energy Sector Privatization (MSC) was established in 1990 under the chairmanship of the Minister of Energy. This Committee is composed largely of policy makers from a wide range of institutions; its role has been to oversee and review the implementation of energy sector projects. The Committee has been strengthened with the creation of an Energy Sector Policy Implementation Unit (ESPTU) in MPUT to ensure timely implementation of GOJ's policy and energy sector projects. A Project Manager, with private sector experience, presently heads the unit. 2.3 The operative institutions in the sector are the Jamaica Public Service Co. (JPS) and the Petroleum Corporation of Jamaica (PCJ). PCJ is a wholly owned state corporation established under the Petroleum Act of 1979, and is a holding company for several subsidiaries. The activities of PCJ and its subsidiaries include importing crude oil and petroleum products, refining crude oil, exporting some products, distributing petroleum products and the exploration, development and management of petroleum resources. It's most important subsidiary is Petrojam, which owns and operates the country's only refinery. Under an agreed
 -5 - program with the World Bank, Petrojam is now being privatized. PCJ's other significant subsidiaries are the Petroleum Company of Jamaica (PETCOM), a petroleum marketing subsidiary established in 1985, and Petronol, established in 1986, which produces ethanol. PCJ is in the process of divesting most of these subsidiaries. At the same time, it has reduced the size of its headquarters staff. The overall structure of petroleum product marketing and distribution is dominated by three local affiliates of international companies (ESSO, Shell and Texaco). 2.4 JPS, the only power utility in Jamaica, has had the sole responsibility for the generation, transmission, and distribution of electric power for public consumption. The GOJ has 99% ownership of the company which reports to MPUT. In addition to JPS, there are a number of private independent generators of electricity who produce power for their own consumption, i.e., the bauxite companies, the Caribbean Cement Company, sugar estates and hotels. Of these, only the bauxite companies are connected to the grid and provide it with a limited amount of electricity. Recently, JPS has entered into a number of arrangements with Independent Power Producers to purchase power. C. Government's Energy Sector Policy 2.5 The Government has a well-defined energy policy. The objectives of the energy policy are to: (a) ensure stable and adequate energy supplies at the least economic cost through a combination of public and private sector participation in a deregulated and liberalized environment; (b) diversify the energy base, encourage the development of indigenous energy resources where economically viable and technically feasible, and ensure the security of energy supplies; (c) encourage efficiency in energy production, conversion and use with the overall objectives of reducing the energy intensity of the economy; (d) complement the country's industrial policy by recognizing the importance of energy as a critical input to industrial growth and stability; (e) minimize the adverse environmental effects and pollution caused by the production, storage, transport and use of energy; and (f) establish an appropriate regulatory framework to protect consumers. investors, the environment and sector entities. 2.6 The government expects to achieve these policy objectives by creating an enabling environment to: (a) encourage private sector participation and investments through a policy of divestment and appropriate regulatory framework; (b) promote the development of indigenous energy sources where appropriate, technically and economically feasible; (c) encourage energy conservation/efficiency on the supply side as well as demand side management; (d) fully protect the environment while ensuring that adequate energy supplies are available to the country and to sustain the desired rate of economic growth; (e) maintain appropriate institutional arrangements to ensure that the stated objectives are achieved; and stimulate industrial development by encouraging synergies from co- generation. The protection of the environment remains a primary objective of the energy policy and as such the environmental guidelines of the National Resource Conservation Authority (NRCA) relating to the energy sector will be enforced.

As long as these contractual arrangements remain favorable from national interest point of view, they will be continued. When the refinery is privatized, it is envisaged that the country will continue to enjoy the benefits of crude oil supplies under the existing contractual arrangements. Given the complete deregulation of the petroleum sector all individuals/entities are now free to import crude and petroleum products. As the government believes that the processing of crude is the desirable option and as such, will encourage refinery operation in the country by way of a tariff differential. 2.8 In this context, the energy policy will: (a) provide competitive advantage for the refining of petroleum through the granting of an appropriate differential between tariffs on refinery feedstock and the importation of fully refined petroleum products; (b) seek to enter into joint venture partnerships with the private sector with regards to the refinery and other government owned energy entities; (c) review and optimize specifications for all petroleum products to meet modern economic and environmental requirements; (d) ensure that importers and marketers of petroleum will be required to supply the appropriate ministry with timely and relevant information regarding imports, sales etc. The provision of this information will be necessary for proper energy planning; (e) seek to ensure access to common terminalling facilities on a transparent basis for all eligible marketers and customers; (f) review and establish the policy for the pricing of petroleum products in order to achieve the objective of withdrawing subsidies and promoting the policy of energy conservation; (g) ensure that petroleum refinery/marketing companies will be required to maintain a predetermined level of inventory. This level of inventory will guarantee that the nation's petroleum supplies are maintained at the required level; and (h) seek to maintain the protection of the environment and the preservation/encouragement of natural and cultivated forests. Although, for example, government will cause overall removal of subsidy on domestic kerosene to be gradually phased out, it will remain committed to some direct subsidy to assist those poor households that can be identified as totally dependent on that petroleum product for cooking and lighting. 2.9 GOJ has already carried out a series of actions to put in place its new sector policy. Under support from Energy Sector Deregulation and Privatization Project (Ln 3502), establishment of ESPIU is assisting MPUT and MSC in the implementation of energy related projects financed by multilateral agencies and the implementation of privatization programs. Implementation of the energy policy entails that: (a) an appropriate ministry will continue to have overall responsibility for the implementation of the policy; (b) the ministry will create a central energy conservation and renewable unit which will act as a facilitator for all new and renewable energy projects. This unit will provide a central point for inputs from the public and the scientific community with regard to technological developments etc. Ongoing information to the public will also be provided by this unit; and (c) the Office of Utility Regulation (OUR), which will cover all utility services, will be established in accordance with the Office of Utilities Regulation

The OUR will have oversight responsibility for the regulatory framework for the energy sector. D. Energy Consumption and Supply 2.10 In comparison with countries at a similar stage of development, the level of energy consumption in Jamaica is fairly high. This is primarily due to the needs of the bauxite and alumina industry which is highly energy intensive. In 1993, Jamaica's gross per capita energy requirement was estimated at about 8.7 barrels of oil equivalent (boe) or 1,309 kg of oil equivalent (kgoe) which compares with the average per capita consumption of 650 kgoe for economies at a similar level of per capita income. When corrected for consumption in the bauxite/alumina industry, which accounts for around 50% of total demand, per capita requirements fall to 650kgoe. 2.11 Commercial energy accounts for 91% oftotal gross energy requirements. On an end use basis, 91 % of commercial energy is used in the form of petroleum, 7% in the form of electricity and about 2% in the form of coal by the cement industry. The bauxite industry accounts for 50% of total energy use, the transport sector for about 17%, the sugar industry for about 5%, and the household sector for about 10%. 2.12 Jamaica's petroleum demand is mainly met through local refining and direct import of refined petroleum products. In 1993, Jamaica imported about 18.3 million barrels (MMB) of petroleum and petroleum products. About 6.6 MMB of refined products were imported directly by the bauxite/alumina industry. With a nominal capacity of 35.5 thousand barrels per day (MBPD)2, the refinery imported 5.4 MMB (17 MBPD) of feedstock and 6.2 MMB (18.6 MBPD) of refined products. Of the total feed stock, crude oil from Mexico and Venezuela accounted for 79.7% and spikes (refined products as part of refinery feedstock) accounted for 20.3%. 2.13 During the past 23 years, gross energy supplies and requirements in Jamaica have increased at 1.8% p. a. Non-bauxite demand has increased at a rate of 1.6% since 1989. Bauxite industry demand is more erratic (it jumped from 3.2 million boe in 1988 to 4.9 million boe in 1989) and was 8 million boe in 1993. Historic income elasticity of demand for non-bauxite energy is estimated at 1.6. It is assumed that in the long run GDP, in real terms, would grow at an average rate of 3% in 1994-95 and at 3.5% thereafter. In the bauxite and alumina sector, demand for energy is projected to increase in line with the rise in alumina production; for every ton of alumina produced, around 2.48 boe of energy are required. Alumina production is projected to increase from 2.9 million tons in 1992 to 3.5 million tons by 1996; 3.75 million tons by 2000; and 4.25 million tons by 2005. Energy Pricing: Petroleum Products 2.14 Refinery-gate petroleum prices were decontrolled, in an initial phase, in September 1990. Every week the refinery publishes ex-refinery billing prices which are based on: reference postings in the US Gulf, freight; ocean losses and insurance costs; imputed terminal and financing costs to supply products ex-terminal; and a tax element which is fixed by the Government. The oil companies add to this price their own operating margins and transport costs, and establish wholesale prices to the retailers. The retail traders add their operational costs and margins and post ex-outlet prices. 2.15 Prices from outlet to outlet and company to company vary, and reflect some element of competition in the market. While the program of decontrolling petroleum prices had proceeded smoothly, it could not achieve the objective of realistic competition until the market was fully decontrolled through the introduction of Caricom Common External Tariffs (CET) on April 1, 1993. CET allows the import of refinery feed stock at a 5% tariff and import of refined products at 15% tariff. 2.16 As of November 1994, retail prices for gasoline were on the order of US$1.14- 1.29/US gallon (USG); diesel fuel retailed at US$1.05-1.15/USG. These prices compare to FOB US Gulf prices of US$0.70/USG for gasoline and US$0.59/USG for diesel oil. The markup is accounted for by duties (US$0.20/USG for gasoline and US$0.1 5/USG for diesel), freight, insurance, handling costs and marketing margins. 2.17 As household kerosene is used for cooking by about 25% of the low income population, it continues to be subsidized. To ensure that the intended consumers benefit from this subsidy, it is sold to the urban and rural households through kerosene peddlers and local shops in tins or bottles. GOJ is considering to decontrol the price of kerosene and introduce kerosene stamps to provide direct subsidy to poor population. GOJ intends to review taxes on two-burner kerosene and gas stoves to determine how to discourage the use of charcoal. The price of kerosene as of October, 1994 was US$0.70/USG. F.  - 10- 3. THE POWER SUB-SECTOR A. Background 3.1 The basic legislation goveming the power sub-sector consists of the Electric Lighting Act of 1890 and the Electricity Development Act of 1974. The Electricity Development Act established the Electricity Authority as the Agency responsible for power sub-sector development. In addition, the Electricity Authority is empowered to regulate the license-holding utilities. Under the electricity legislation, GOJ granted to JPS, in 1978, a 39-year "All Island Electric License", which gives JPS the monopoly to supply electricity to all parts of the island, as the sole supplier of electricity for public consumption. 3.2 Although the Electricity Authority exists as a legal entity, in practice the functions of this agency are carried out by MPUT. JPS provides monthly financial reports to MPUT. MPUT is closely involved in JPS' investment plans and operating budgets. Rate adjustment requests are filed to MPUT. After review and analysis, MPUT submits its recommendations on rate adjustments to the Cabinet for final approval. B. Government's Power Sector Policy 3.3 GOJ has taken the decision to deregulate and liberalized the electricity sector, thereby allowing Independent Power Producers (IPP) to be the main players within the sector, with the government becoming a minority partner. In this regard, all new generating capacity is to be provided by private developers. GOJ has also announced its intention to privatize JPS and invited applications from intemational companies for prequalification to bid. These are major policy initiatives which are aimed at moving the entire system of generation, transmission and distribution into private sector ownership and management. Major policy initiatives, therefore, in the power sector are to ensure that an appropriate regulatory framework is put in place to: (a) facilitate the timely provision of new power generating capacity and the associated transmission works; (b) establish an environment capable of attracting private investments in the power sector and capable of supporting long term financing for the private sector; and (c) generally support Jamaica's power sector privatization program. 3.4 The policy is intended to ensure that: (a) all new generation projects are undertaken by the private sector; (b) the potential of co-generation to meet some portion of electricity supply will be pursued and principles under which the electricity company purchases electricity from co-generators, are clearly set out; (c) the company responsible for generation capacity planning prepares a periodic least cost expansion plan for review and approval of the competent authority; (d) the widespread publication of the indicative least cost plan provides guidance to potential private sector investors in the development of proposals for new plants; (e) appropriate regulatory oversight is put in place; (f)
 - 11 - electricity rate setting mechanism reflects the cost of power from private suppliers; and (g) the Rural Electrification Programme (REP) is continued in order to maintain the extension of electricity to rural areas with a view to fostering economic development and improving the quality of life in rural communities. 3.5 Rate setting principles being followed by the power sector are: (a) rates should reflect full costs including duties and taxes; (b) overall revenue requirements to be established on the basis of existing loan agreements with international agencies and GOJ to meet rate of return and/or self-financing tests; (c) indexing of foreign exchange and fuel rate adjustment; and (d) tariffs to be structured according to long run marginal cost principles reflecting peak and off-peak costs, voltage levels, capacity and energy costs. The cost of long term power purchase agreements would also be reflected in the tariffs. It was agreed that JPS will commission a comprehensive long run marginal cost study which will be used as a basis for restructuring the tariffs. C. Electricity Demand and Supply 3.6 In FY93/94, JPS's system generated a total of 2,266 GWh and the gross system peak was 382 MW.  - 64 - Annex 4-1 JAMAICA PUBLIC SERVICE Generation Recovery And Improvement Project Description Background On June 3rd, 1994 the Jamaica Public Service Company Ltd. (JPS) suffered a significant reduction to its power generating capacity due to an explosion and fire at the Old Harbour Power Station. The explosion resulted in a complete loss of the unit number 4 boiler and associated auxiliaries and substantial damage to the boiler of unit number 3. Further, a substantial part of the unit number 4 electrical equipment and cabling were burned and neighbouring buildings were destroyed or severely damaged. The incident has resulted in a total reduction of 124 MW from the total available capacity of 569 MW prior to the incident. As a result of the above JPS reserve margin has dropped from 49% down to 17% causing severe system unreliability. JPS is presently taking steps to restore its generating capacity back to an acceptable level. Among several steps to be taken is the repair and rehabilitation of the Unit number 3 boiler and the procurement and installation of a replacement boiler to be used with the existing 68 MW turbine set at the Old Harbour Power Station Unit Number 4. In addition, this project will include the replacement of all electric equipment, cabling, instrumentation and switch gear, control building, chemical laboratory and stores buildings which were damaged during the explosion. JPS will also be pursuing a life extension programme for the Unit number 4 turbine generator set and associated auxiliary systems to enable the unit to be operable for a further 20 to 30 years. Unit number 3 at the Old Harbour Power Station is scheduled to be back in operation by February 1995 and the restoration programme is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 1995. Credits are provided for transformer ownership and primary metering. All rates incorporate a fuel adjustment clause which provides for an automatic (albeit lagged) adjustment according to fuel cost variations, and a foreign exchange adjustment clause which allows Jamaica Public Service Company Ltd. (JPS) to recover tariff loss due to exchange rate changes, linked to its foreign currency expenses (estimated to be on average 75% of its total costs). Concerning tariff levels, although JPS average tariff level compares favorably with other countries in the region, Coopers & Lybrand (C&L) performed a preliminary evaluation of long- run marginal costs as part of the restructuring study. It found that existing average tariffs exceeded average marginal costs by about 15%. Additionally, the study showed that significant differences existed between tariffs and marginal cost for individual customer categories, ranging from +35% for residential customers to -3% for power service. C&L warned that due to the limited information available on customer load characteristics, results for individual customer categories should be used cautiously. As part of the Power IV Project (Loan 2869-JM) a load research program is being carried out in order to determine reliable load composition parameters which can be used for the assessment and allocation of costs for tariff setting purposes. In view of the planned changes in the regulatory framework for electricity supply and JPS privatization process the current electricity pricing system and tariff structure may require modifications. Especially the following issues need to be addressed: (1) the tariff does not follow the structure of the costs of future supply; (2) the tariff does not provide customers with adequate signals for efficient use of electricity in particular since rates do not reflect peak and off peak supply costs; (3) generation costs are expected to change when JPS is privatized and purchases from independent power producers increases.

 Annex 6-14 Page 1 of 2 JAMAICA PUBLIC SERVICE COMPANY NOTES ON FINANCIAL STATEMENTS Regulation: The company operates under an exclusive thirty-nine year All-island Electric License granted on August 31, 1978. Under the provisions of the License the operations of the company are subject to regulation by the Minister of Public Utilities with power and authority to require observance and performance by the company of its obligations under the License, and to regulate the rates charged by the company. Ownership: The govemment is the owner of approximately 99% of the issued ordinary share capital of the company, through the Electricity Authority and the Accountant General. Summary of Accounting Policies: The records of the company are maintained in accordance with the regulations prescribed for Public Utilities by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission of the United States, in so far as these regulations allow compliance with the Companies Act, the License and directives from the Minister. (a) Utility plant and depreciation: In accordance with the License, utility plant and replacement of retirement units of property are capitalized and include direct labor, materials, indirect charges for administration, transportation and similar items, reduced by non-refundable contributions in-aid of construction. The company capitalizes an allowance for funds used during construction based on its average cost of funds. Replacement of minor items of property are included in maintenance expenses. The replacement cost of depreciable units of plant retired is eliminated from utility plant accounts and such value plus removal expenses, less salvage, is charged to accumulated depreciation. In accordance with the License, depreciation of utility plant is computed using a straight line basis on the replacement cost of such asset in service at the beginning of each month. The rates used are in accordance with the License, the composite rate being approximately 4% per annum. (b) Materials and supplies: These include construction materials and fuel stocks and stated at average cost.
 - 112- Annex 6-14 Page 2 of 2 (c) Revenue Accounts receivable and unbilled revenue: Revenue consists of cycle billings rendered to customers monthly or bi-monthly with an accrual for revenue earned but billed subsequent to the end of the period. Accounts receivable represent the amount due from customers for billed services less a provision for doubtful accounts. Unbilled revenue represents the accrual for electricity supplied prior to the year end which is billed subsequently. (d) Deferred expenditures: (i) Debt discount and expenses include issue expenses, commitment fees and similar items which are being amortized over the lives of the loans to which they relate; and (ii) Other consist of costs which are expected to benefit future periods; these are deferred and are either amortized over their expected periods of benefit, transferred to plant and equipment or charged against income as appropriate. (e) Foreign exchange translation: Assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currencies are translated at the rates of exchange prevailing on the balance sheet date. Any losses or gains not forming part of the revaluation are reflected in income. (f) Taxation: Taxation is only recorded if taxable income results from computations made in accordance with Taxation note (a) below. No charges or credits for deferred taxation are recorded. (g) Pension costs: Pension costs are charged to expense to the extent of actual company contributions payable based on percentage of employee pensionable earnings. Taxation: (a) The principal differences in computing the profit for accounting purposes and the taxable profit are: (i) investment allowances equivalent to 20% of the cost of the additions to plant are granted for tax purposes; (ii) tax depreciation is significantly less than depreciation charged against profit; (iii) the allowance for funds used during construction is not included in the profit for tax purposes nor is the allowance included in the written down value of fixed assets for tax purposes; (iv) preference dividends are deductible for tax purposes; and (v) interest is claimable for tax purposes when paid instead of when charged. (b) Taxation is based on the profit for the year adjusted for taxation purposes. (c) During FY93, an appraisal of the company's plant in service was conducted by Stone and Webster Management Consultants Incorporated and local independent valuators. Land and buildings were restated to current market value and depreciated current replacement cost is used.

doc.abstracts: The Generation Recovery and Improvement Project has the fololwing objectives: 1) to restore electricity service to normal conditions as early as possible, thus eliminating costly power cuts; 2) to reduce generation costs through lower running cost plants, save on capital costs by upgrading existing facilities and safeguard the system against the breakdown of existing units due to extended use; 3) to improve generation security, enhance system reliability and control systems to reduce the likelihood of future recurrence of generating plant incidents by improving the telecommunications and energy control systems and by reinforcing the transmission network; 4) to improve resource allocation through the reform of electricity tariffs and ensure that loss of base load generation capacity does not adversely affect the environment for increasing private sector participation in the power sector; and 4) to reduce and control the environmental impact associated with power system facilities. To achieve these objectives the project comprises several components. The first is a restoration of Old Habor (OH) unit 3 and OH unit 4 boiler. Second, the project calls for life extension of OH unit 4 generation turbine and upgrades for gas turbine units 3, 4 and 5. Transmission system reinforcements and ugrading of the energy control center and associated telecommunications facilities are also major concerns. Additionally, consulting services will be required for technical supervision and project management for the generating system components of the project; engineering and management for the environmental mitigation component of the project; and cost of service and tariff reform studies.
